4.1    Accidental Release Prevention Policies

The CWTP has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Gaseous Chlorine Disinfection System.  The CWTP's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance. 

4.2    Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines.  The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 20,000 pounds of chlorine kept in ten (10) one-ton containers.  Chlorine leak detection and warning is provided by high and low chlorine sensor alarms to control room with an audible and visual alarm system.  

4.3    Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis 

The Off-site Consequence Analysis must be reviewed every five years or within six months of process changes or other changes that may significantly affect the results of the Off-site Consequence Analysis.



Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Gaseous Chlorine Disinfection System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  



Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary

Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the Gaseous Chlorine Disinfection System.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.  

4.4    Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the CWTP has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to

the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release.  The facility has chlorine detectors that activate a Scrubber System.

4.5    Accidental Release Prevention Program 

As part of the implementation of the CalARP/EPA RMP Program for the Chlorination System, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by CWTP to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine for water treatment.  Furthermore, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.

The facility maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 20,000 lbs.  Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 2,500-lbs. threshold for EPA RMP, the 1,500-lbs. threshold for Cal/OSHA PSM and the 100-lbs. state threshold for the CalARP Program.  As a result, the chlorine covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?    19 CCR ? 2760.1 Process Safety Information (PSI)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.3 Operating Procedures (OP)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.4 Training (TRN)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.5 Mechanical Integrity (MI)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.6 Management of Change (MOC)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.7 Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.8 Compliance Audits (CA)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.9 Incident Investigation (II)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.10 Employee Participation (EP)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.11 Hot Work Permit (HWP)

?    19 CCR ? 2760.12 Contractors (CON)

In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Emergency Response Program (see 4.7 Emergency Response Program below).

4.6    Five-Year Accident History 

There have been no CalARP applicable releases of chlorine or accidents from a release of the covered process resulting in death, injuries, or significant property damage at CWTP in the past five years.

4.7    Emergency Response Program

The CWTP personnel are not first responders, in the event of an emergency they would contact local responders.  The CWTP has submitted a Hazardous Materials Business Plan in order to coordinate with the local emergency planning and response agencies to ensure that in an event of an emergency they are properly prepared and have knowledge of the system.

4.8    External Events Analysis

Pursuant to the requirements of California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Section 2745.7 (q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of chlorine were addressed by the PHA.  

4.9    Planned Changes To Improve Safety 

The Compliance Audit has been conducted to examine any deficiencies at the Program 3 facility improve the safety program.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the October 2019 Compliance Audit Report.

4.10    Flammables: Worst Case 

The use of flammable materials at the CWTP facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.  

4.11    Flammables: Alternative Release 

The use of flammable materials at the CWTP facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.



The PHA was due May 2019 but is scheduled to be completed in February 2020 so that the anniversary date of both the Water Treatment Plant and the other Calexico facility may have the same anniversary date for future program maintenance.
